verses.text: Rejoice in the LORD, you righteous! Praise is fitting for those who are upright.
verses.comment: The Psalm opens with a call for the righteous to rejoice, highlighting that worship is especially suited for those who live in fidelity to God. This connects with the biblical theme that true praise arises from upright hearts (cf. Ps 51:17).

verses.text: Give thanks to the LORD with the lyre; make music to Him on a ten-stringed harp.
verses.comment: The use of musical instruments is encouraged in giving thanks and worship, reflecting the practice of liturgical music in biblical worship, which continues in Christian tradition. The specific mention of instruments underscores the beauty and order proper to the worship of God.

verses.text: Sing to Him a new song; play skillfully with a shout of joy.
verses.comment: A 'new song' signifies renewed praise for God's ongoing work in salvation history. The call for skillful music and joyful noise hints at a worship that engages both the heart and the senses, echoing the worship of heaven (Rev 5:9).

verses.text: For the word of the LORD is upright, and all His work is done in faithfulness.
verses.comment: The integrity of God's word is the foundation of His faithfulness. Christians see in this a foreshadowing of the incarnate Word, who is utterly trustworthy (Jn 1:1; Rev 19:11–13).

verses.text: He loves righteousness and justice; the earth is full of the LORD's steadfast love.
verses.comment: Love, righteousness, and justice characterize God's dealings with humanity. The pervasive 'steadfast love' (Hebrew: hesed) points to the faithful mercy and grace that fill creation.

verses.text: By the word of the LORD the heavens were made, and by the breath of His mouth all their host.
verses.comment: Creation by God's word suggests the power and authority of His speech. Christians see clear echoes of Christ as the eternal Word who brings forth creation (John 1:1-3; Col 1:16). The 'breath' (Spirit) connects to the role of the Holy Spirit in creation.

verses.text: He gathers the waters of the sea as in a heap; He stores up the deeps in storehouses.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over the chaotic waters alludes to His control over creation and points symbolically to the order He brings, which prefigures Christian baptism where chaotic waters become instruments of grace (1 Pet 3:21).

verses.text: Let all the earth fear the LORD; let all the inhabitants of the world stand in awe of Him.
verses.comment: The universal call to fear and awe before God anticipates the mission to all nations and the unity of worship found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: For He spoke, and it came to be; He commanded, and it stood firm.
verses.comment: God's word is effective and creative. This is foundational for faith in the trustworthy promises and sacraments God ordains, which are effective because of His command.

verses.text: The LORD frustrates the plans of the nations; He thwarts the purposes of the peoples.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty reigns over human politics and ambitions. This is a reminder for Christian unity and confidence in God's ultimate plan that transcends any earthly scheme.

verses.text: But the counsel of the LORD stands forever, the plans of His heart to all generations.
verses.comment: Unlike human plans, God's purpose is eternal and steadfast. The reference to 'all generations' suggests a divinely guided tradition that persists through Church history.

verses.text: Blessed is the nation whose God is the LORD, the people He has chosen as His heritage.
verses.comment: The special blessing on the people of God prefigures the spiritual nation described in 1 Peter 2:9, called to be God's own possession.

verses.text: The LORD looks down from heaven; He sees all the children of man.
verses.comment: God's watchful gaze is universal. Nothing escapes His sight, reinforcing the reality of both individual and communal accountability to Him.

verses.text: From where He sits enthroned, He looks out on all the inhabitants of the earth.
verses.comment: The image of God enthroned points to His royal and judicial authority over all creation, anticipating Christ’s reign from His heavenly throne (Heb 1:3).

verses.text: He forms the hearts of them all; He considers all their works.
verses.comment: God not only observes actions, but knows and shapes the inner life of every person. Such intimate knowledge is a foundation for the spiritual life and reliance on divine guidance.

verses.text: The king is not saved by his great army; a warrior is not delivered by his great strength.
verses.comment: Salvation is from the Lord, not human power. This principle echoes the entire narrative of redemption, seen most fully in the humble sacrifice of Christ (Phil 2:6-8).

verses.text: The horse is a false hope for salvation; by its great might it cannot rescue.
verses.comment: Earthly means of deliverance are contrasted with the true hope found in God. Christians see here a subtle hint toward the necessity of reliance on divine grace rather than mere human effort.

verses.text: Behold, the eye of the LORD is on those who fear Him, on those who hope in His steadfast love,
verses.comment: God's special providence rests on those who maintain reverent awe and trust in His covenant love. This emphasizes both faith and 'the fear of the Lord' as central virtues.

verses.text: that He may deliver their soul from death and keep them alive in famine.
verses.comment: Deliverance from death and need points to the full salvation God offers. Early Christians interpreted physical rescue as prefiguring the spiritual salvation and the sustenance God provides, especially through sacred means.

verses.text: Our soul waits for the LORD; He is our help and our shield.
verses.comment: Hopeful expectation and trust in the Lord are themes central to the life of faith. The image of God as both help and shield resonates with Christian teaching on spiritual warfare and perseverance.

verses.text: For our heart rejoices in Him, because we trust in His holy name.
verses.comment: Trust in the holy name of God is the basis for true joy. In Christian tradition, the name carries the personal presence and authority of God Himself (Acts 4:12).

verses.text: Let Your steadfast love, O LORD, be upon us, even as we hope in You.
verses.comment: The psalm concludes with a prayer for steadfast love (hesed) according to hope. This underlines the ongoing need for God's covenant mercy and points forward to the fulfillment of hope in the new covenant.
